issues.title: Strategy & Alignment
issues.body: Ensure all stakeholders and the delivery team share a single understanding of goals, scope, and constraints before development begins.

children.title: Define business objectives and success criteria
children.body: Establish what success looks like for this project. Document measurable goals and key metrics.

children.title: Confirm in-scope and out-of-scope modules
children.body: Agree on what is included and excluded from this project. Make sure everyone knows what modules will be built based on dropped draft items.

children.title: Agree on delivery timeline and release expectations
children.body: Confirm the schedule, milestones, and what users expect to receive and when.

children.title: Identify and assess technical, resource, and dependency risks
children.body: Identify potential technical, resource, and dependency risks. Create plans to reduce these risks.

children.title: Get stakeholder sign-off on scope and timeline
children.body: Have all stakeholders review and approve the scope and plan.

issues.title: Requirements & Analysis
issues.body: Translate business needs into a clear, prioritized product backlog that can be executed incrementally.

children.title: Identify functional workflows (Master Data, Movements, Inventory, Reports)
children.body: Document how materials move through the warehouse - from receiving goods to storing them to picking for orders. Include all the steps, decisions, and approvals needed.

children.title: Define user roles and access levels
children.body: Create different user types (admin, warehouse staff, managers) and decide what each can do. Define security rules for protecting important data.

children.title: Capture non-functional requirements (performance, security, auditability)
children.body: Write down what the system must handle - how many transactions per day, speed requirements, backup and recovery needs, and compliance rules.

children.title: Identify dependencies between modules
children.body: Map out how different parts of the system depend on each other. Know which work must happen first.

children.title: Create acceptance criteria at feature level
children.body: For each feature, define how to test if it works correctly. Write the success criteria.

issues.title: Architecture & Design
issues.body: Create a stable technical foundation that supports parallel development and future scaling.

children.title: Finalize application architecture (desktop, layered, service-based)
children.body: Plan the overall system layout - what components exist, how they connect, and how they communicate. Make sure it can handle future growth.

children.title: Define database and integration design (high level)
children.body: Create the data model showing what information we need to store, what tables exist, and how they relate to each other.

children.title: Define module boundaries and data flow
children.body: Establish clear interfaces between different system modules. Define how they talk to each other.

children.title: Design UI/UX structure and navigation flow
children.body: Sketch out the screens, navigation flow, and how users will interact with the system. Make sure it's easy and consistent.

children.title: Design security and authorization model
children.body: Design how users log in, how we verify who they are, what they're allowed to do, and how we keep the system secure.

issues.title: Development - Execution Phase
issues.body: Deliver the full system in two balanced development phases, each accounting for approximately 50% of total functionality. Development intentionally overlaps with planning, hardening, and release activities to reduce risk.

children.title: Phase 1 - Core Functionality
children.body: Build the functional backbone of the system so that core warehouse operations are executable end-to-end. Build application infrastructure, all master data modules, core warehouse movements, and inventory services. By end of Phase 1: secure login, warehouse setup, material/vendor/customer configuration, and end-to-end goods receipt → putaway → picking → goods issue flow.

children.body: Build the foundation that everything else runs on. Set up the application, database, security, and user accounts. Sanod is responsible for the core infrastructure that all other developers depend on.

children.body: Build entry point, main window, and login screen.

children.title: Create configuration and utility files (AppConfig.java, SystemParameters.java, MenuBuilder.java, DashboardPanel.java)
children.body: Build application configuration, system parameters, menu builder, and dashboard panel.

children.title: Set up database connection infrastructure (DatabaseConfig.java, DBConnection.java, DatabaseHelper.java)
children.body: Make sure the application connects to the database safely and reliably.

children.title: Build complete database schema design and PHP API implementation
children.body: Complete database schema design and implementation. Create all PHP API endpoints (Material, Vendor, Customer, PurchaseOrder, SalesOrder, etc.).

children.title: Create authentication and security system (UserSession.java, UserAuthentication.java, PermissionManager.java)
children.body: Let users log in safely and check what they're allowed to do.

children.body: Create data model for user management.

children.body: Log errors and important events so we can debug problems later.

children.title: Complete infrastructure integration testing and performance tuning
children.body: End-to-end testing and optimization of infrastructure components.

issues.title: Testing & Quality Assurance
issues.body: Ensure quality is built into development. Testing happens continuously within both phases AND we reserve time for final system-level QA after Phase 2.

children.title: Set up testing framework and test data
children.body: Set up JUnit framework. Create test database with sample data. Build test data generation utilities.

children.title: Unit test all core infrastructure components
children.body: Write unit tests for infrastructure, security, and core services. Test database connectivity and configuration.

children.title: Unit test all master data modules
children.body: Write unit tests for material, vendor, customer models. Test form validation and data persistence.

children.title: Unit test all movement modules
children.body: Write unit tests for inbound, outbound, and transfer movements. Test inventory update logic and FIFO implementation.

children.title: Integration test complete end-to-end workflows
children.body: Test end-to-end: GR → Putaway → Picking → GI flow. Validate data consistency across all modules.

children.title: Test with realistic sample data and user scenarios
children.body: Create realistic test data and run through all system features. Make sure the system handles real warehouse scenarios.

children.title: Perform performance and load testing
children.body: Test system performance under load. Validate database optimization. Test concurrent user access.

children.title: Perform security validation and compliance testing
children.body: Test authentication and authorization. Validate data encryption. Test audit logging.

children.title: Conduct user acceptance testing
children.body: Have actual warehouse staff test the system and give feedback. Validate against business requirements.

issues.title: Hardening, Deployment & Release
issues.body: Prepare the system for real-world usage.

children.title: Perform system hardening and optimization
children.body: Optimize database queries and services. Fix remaining bugs. Perform stress testing and tuning.

children.title: Create deployment packages and installation documentation
children.body: Package the Java application. Include database scripts and configuration files. Create installation instructions.

children.title: Perform final security audit and validation
children.body: Review user permissions. Test backup and recovery. Verify security protocols.

children.title: Create release notes and deployment documentation
children.body: Document new features, enhancements, known issues, and workarounds.

children.title: Execute production deployment and database migration
children.body: Deploy system to production environment. Execute database migration. Configure production settings.

issues.title: Documentation, Training & Handover
issues.body: Ensure smooth adoption and long-term maintainability.

children.title: Create comprehensive user manuals and guides

children.title: Create administrator and system guides

children.title: Create technical and developer documentation
children.body: Document system architecture and design decisions. Create developer guides. Document data models and APIs.

children.title: Conduct knowledge transfer and training sessions
children.body: Train administrators on system management. Train warehouse staff on daily operations. Prepare support team for handover.

children.title: Provide post-deployment support and optimization
children.body: Support users during initial rollout. Fix any issues that arise. Optimize based on real-world usage.
